page.title: 01TRANSPORT_RAILWAYS
page.content: 1985 is the 150th anniversary of the Great Western Railway.Perranporth played its own part in this,by being a most popular stop on the Chacewater to Newquay branch line.The line was first opened in 1903 and was closed as part of the economies made in 1963 by "Beechings Axe".There were thirteen stops on the line,which was eighteen miles long.A full journey took 57 minutes. Many people in the village have fond memories of the line.Often the guard would hold the train for local people. Once a local joker turned the station lights out at Perranporth and the train whistled through without stopping,much to the amusement of everyone,including the local police. Little remains now,apart from a viaduct visible at Goonbell and the restored station house at St.Agnes.
